Appeal of FOIA Request #23-01864-FOIA Expedited Process Determination. I am writing to appeal the determination made in response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request, which was assigned Request #23-01864-FOIA. The initial response stated that my request did not qualify for expedited processing on the grounds that I "failed to show that there is an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual." I respectfully request that you reconsider this determination, as I believe it was improperly applied. I would like to bring to your attention that the determination made by your agency is not the sole determinant for expedition under both extant law and established case law. The criteria for expediting FOIA requests is explicitly defined by statutes, and the decision must be considered in the broader context of applicable legal standards and relevant case precedents. As stipulated by the Department of Justice (DOJ) Regulation, the requester must demonstrate two key factors to qualify for expedited processing: That the request involves a "matter of widespread and exceptional media interest" (28 C.F.R. § 16.5(e)(1)(iv)). That the matter is one "in which there exists possible questions about the integrity of the government that affect public confidence" (28 C.F.R. § 16.5(e)(1)(iv)). In support of my appeal, I wish to emphasize that my request meets both of these criteria. The matter at hand, which pertains to potential domestic influence by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), is unquestionably of widespread and exceptional media interest. It is widely recognized that matters related to foreign influence in domestic affairs have garnered significant public attention and media coverage. Furthermore, the context of my FOIA request aligns with the requirement that there exist "possible questions about the integrity of the government that affect public confidence." Courts, such as in the case of Edmonds v. FBI, have clarified that it is not necessary to demonstrate prejudice or an immediate exigency to the American public to qualify for expedited processing. Rather, the focus is on matters that raise legitimate questions about government integrity, particularly those that could impact public confidence in the government's ability to address these issues adequately, such as ability for the Biden administration to handle CCP influence domestically, grants to affiliated corporate structures, etc.
